title: [Question] Lodash modularize
Support to toArray for Sets
body:
Current behaviour:

```
var set = new Set()
set.add('value')
_.toArray(set) // => []
```

I'd expect that `toArray` should be able to handle Sets and return an array of their values, rather than always returning the empty array.

title: Support for Keyed collections
body:
ES6 has a few builtin collection types 
- Map
- Set
- WeakMap
- WeakSet

Does lodash support, or plan to support these? If not, is there a reason that they are not included?

title: Update CONTRIBUTING.md with info about the state of the master branch
body:
Hey there! First, thanks for Lodash, freakin' awesome!

I just spent a good deal of time crawling around the repository trying to figure out why the tests are not running on master, where `lodash.js` is and what I'm doing wrong. 

Then I found the modularization commit and its comments and it all became clear. My first step 
(before walking around the repo) was to read CONTRIBUTING.md, but there was nothing in there that would explain the current situation. 

So I propose a change to CONTRIBUTING with a small notice about the current state of master, and the last commit with working `package.json` scripts. This can be removed when `master` is ready to take contributions again.

title: fp/throttle expecting arguments in wrong order
Inconsistent behavior for JS and TS 'result' method
body:
Hi,

I'm not sure if you have any affiliation with the **@types/lodash** NPM package contained in the [DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped) repo or not, but I thought you may be able to help.

I'm using the @types/lodash package from NPM and getting inconsistent behavior for it's `_.result(object, path, [defaultValue])` method.

You are supposed to be able to provide a nested path as the second parameter, but the @types/lodash version is only working for top level properties on the object.

Using `_` from [lodash docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#result)

I'm at version **4.14.45**. Could these unmet peer dependencies be causing an issue?

It would be exactly like [_.pullAt](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#pullAt), but it would instead return an array without values at indexes anymore. This would balance the api a bit. Also other vice versa functions compared to pullX -functions would be good to have. 

I know there is _.remove, but it's a bit cumbersome as you need to pass function to it instead of index.

E: Umm.. I was thinking about drafting a pr of this, but i couldn't find tests from master. Is master branch currently in some transition phase to es6 modules perhaps?

title: _.get from object with numeric keys
Question - another name for map & pick?
body:
Apologies if this is a newbie question. I keep finding myself writing this:

    var someArray = [{  // Array of objects, each of which contains several properties
        uid: 0,
        useful: 'something important',
        other: 'meta data which can be ignored',
        ...
    },{
    ...
    }]
    _.map(someArray, item => _.pick(item, ['uid', 'useful']))  // Get an array of 'slimmed down' objects

to get a version of the array of objects containing only a subset of properties. Is there a simpler / combined `_` function which does the job of map and pick together? Something like:

    _.pickAll(someArray, ['uid', 'useful'])

I wondered if `_.invokeMap()` could be used, but I couldn't figure out how to pass `_.pick()` as the 'path'

Would this be helpful?
We can add more of these if this is approved.

This could really help people discover functions in Lodash, that they didn't know about before.

title: Entry point in v5.0.0
body:
Another v5 question. :)

I'm really excited for the removal of the monolith entry point and separate method packages -- it was always a pain to have some dependencies import from "lodash", others from "lodash/x", and still others from "lodash.x", unnecessarily ~tripling the amount of Lodash being loaded.

However, will there be an entry point which simply re-exports all of the modules? I'd love to be able to `import {map, reduce} from 'lodash'` _without_ using babel-plugin-lodash (recognizing that I'm bringing in the entire bundle by doing so).

title: Removal of _.omit in v5.0.0?
body:
I noticed that `_.omit` has been removed in master, [slated for v5.0.0](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Roadmap). I couldn't find any discussion of the decision; I'm just wondering why you've chosen to remove it.

FWIW, it's one of my most frequently used Lodash methods. The roadmap suggests using `_.pick` instead, but it's not clear how that supports my typical use case: I want to remove keys `x` and `y`, but I don't know the structure of the rest of the object, so I don't know which remaining keys to pick. Maybe I'm missing something?

Cheers.

title: Webpack 2 Breaking Change breaks lodash-es
body:
In the [v2.2.0-rc-4 Release](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/releases/tag/v2.2.0-rc.4) webpack introduced a Breaking Change: 
"Using CommonJS or AMD export stuff in a ES2015 module will emit errors."

This now causes builds to exit with an Error when using lodash-es:
```
...
    ERROR in ./~/lodash-es/isBuffer.js
    8:91-97 module is not allowed in EcmaScript module: This module was detected as EcmaScript module (import or export syntax was used). In such a module using 'module' is not allowed.

    ERROR in ./~/lodash-es/_nodeUtil.js
    4:25-32 exports is not allowed in EcmaScript module: This module was detected as EcmaScript module (import or export syntax was used). In such a module using 'exports' is not allowed.
...
```
Related: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/3917

title: forEach is not a function error in some browsers
body:
I am getting Sentry errors from a small subset of users telling me that there is a problem:
`TypeError: n.forEach is not a function` when loading lodash (n is from minifying).

The user agent strings of the browsers are the following:
```
Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/7.0)
Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux i686; rv:20.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/20.0
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:18.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/18.0
```

Now it seems like Firefoxes are really old as well as IE is some weird version or compatibility mode, so I'm totally OK to just have these browsers brake.

I've opened this ticket for the following reasons:
1. It might be useful for you to know that n.forEach is breaking on some browsers.
2. Ask what minimum IE and Firefox versions can I safely say are compatible with lodash? Readme says IE11+ but tests are run on IE9+. So which one? 

Lodash is 4.x latest.

title: Explain "Many lodash methods are guarded to work as iteratees"
body:
The [docs for _.map][1] say:

> Many lodash methods are guarded to work as iteratees for methods like _.every, _.filter, _.map, _.mapValues, _.reject, and _.some.
>
> The guarded methods are:
> ary, chunk, curry, curryRight, drop, dropRight, every, fill, invert, parseInt, random, range, rangeRight, repeat, sampleSize, slice, some, sortBy, split, take, takeRight, template, trim, trimEnd, trimStart, and words

I haven't been able to find an explanation of what "guarded to work as iteratees" means in the documentation or elsewhere. Some detail or an example here would be greatly appreciated.

[1]: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#map

title: The "modern environments" link in README.md

title: Debounce Trailing Documentation Unclear
body:
### Issue
From [the docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#debounce):
> Note: If leading and trailing options are true, func is invoked on the trailing edge of the timeout only if the debounced function is invoked more than once during the wait timeout.

To me, this makes it seem like if the debounced function is only called once, it will _not_ be called on the trailing edge.

#### Reproduce
However, the reality is that even if the debounced function is only called once, it will wait until the timeout completes before it is invoked. I made a [Codepen here](http://codepen.io/baldwmic/pen/GrgYNg) to confirm this.

#### Example
For example, we debounce a function as follows
```
const debouncedFunction = _.debounce(() => {
  console.log('Function invoked!');
}, 1000, { trailing: true });
```

And if we call it only once
```
debouncedFunction();
```

The docs make it seem like this will not wait 1 second to invoke the function that logs to the console.

### Discussion
Does that make sense?

title: [Question] normal / es builds
body:
This is just a general question, but you might be the person knowing the ultimate answer ;)

I'm exploring possibilities for structuring other package and searching for the way to:
- support both umd and es builds (thanks to main and jsnext:main used by 'modern' bundlers)
- with cherry-picked features like in lodash

I would like to keep the same package name, and it would be great if cherry-picks could also be imported in the same way (like `import assign from 'lodash/assign'`) for both builds.

So far I've came to conclusion that this is simply not possible and I feel you have explored the area in the past and could confirm/deny this conclusion.

Thanks in advance and sorry for bothering with this on the `lodash` issues, but in the same time it could be treated as a question if `lodash` could be organized in such a manner so wehn switching bundler type all of the code could stay exactly the same in order to leverage tree-shaking.

title: Add note about curry/curryRight and rest parameter/default values
body:
In reference to a gitter conversation https://gitter.im/lodash/lodash?at=585ad8f061e516c1578ea1a7

`_.curry` and `_.curryRight` don't work "as expected" when used with functions containing rest parameters or parameters with defaults. And they shouldn't considering how Function::length is specified.

Though I don't believe it is the job of Lodash to educate JS devs about the features of their language, I suspect this knowledge is far from common. A note or discussion would be helpful to anyone attempting, unsuccessfully, to use these sorts of functions w/ `_.curry` and `_.curryRight`.

title: Does _.intersection in version 3.10.1 preserve sort order of the first array?
body:
This question has been previously asked in issue #779

In version 4.17.2 it is stated in the API documentation that "order and references are determined by the first array" however this is not documented in version 3.10.1

Looking at the source in 3.10.1, it appears to be preserving the order of the first array provided as it is iterating over the elements in arrays[0] and pushing the intersecting elements to the result array.

title: Surprising behaviour for _.unset on array keys - consistent with Javascript native and JSON so closing
body:
```_.unset``` behaved as I would expect for paths made of text keys mapping recursively to object properties, but it did not behave as I would expect for numeric keys mapping recursively to Array entries. 

However, my expectations were wrong, as I hadn't recognised how ```delete arr[0]``` was actually handled by Javascript, and lodash just reflects this.

## Object case - works as expected

```
> var root = {"grandparent":{"parent":{}}}
undefined
> lodash.set(root, ['grandparent','parent','child'], "value")
{ grandparent: { parent: { child: 'value' } } }
> JSON.stringify(root)
'{"grandparent":{"parent":{"child":"value"}}}'
> lodash.unset(root, ['grandparent','parent','child'])
true
> JSON.stringify(root)
'{"grandparent":{"parent":{}}}'
```

## Array case - unset leaves an entry appearing as null in JSON.stringify, rather than returning to an empty array.

```
> var root = {"grandparent":{"parent":[]}}
undefined
> lodash.set(root, ['grandparent','parent',0], "value")
{ grandparent: { parent: [ 'value' ] } }
> JSON.stringify(root)
'{"grandparent":{"parent":["value"]}}'
> lodash.unset(root, ['grandparent','parent',0])
true
> JSON.stringify(root)
'{"grandparent":{"parent":[null]}}'
```

This didn't seem at all to be the complementary behaviour to ```_.set```. Instead of calling the equivalent of ```delete``` on the array entry, it seemed to insert a null value in its place.  

However, this is because ```delete root.grandparent.parent[0]``` actually leaves an undefined value i position 0 of parent (which is then a sparse array, still of length 1 but with a single undefined entry at 0). However, confusingly, JSON stringify coerces it to a null (to force it to be valid JSON).

title: _.filter: Property "In" Array Support
_.debounce() breaks fake timers
body:
# _.debounce() breaks fake timers

In tests, it's common to replace JS timer methods such as `setTimeout` and `setInterval` with fake methods in order to control the passage of time. See [Jest Timer Mocks](https://facebook.github.io/jest/docs/timer-mocks.html) and [Sinon Fake Timers](http://sinonjs.org/docs/#clock). Doing this allows you to march the clock forward in tests, executing all timers synchronously. 

Recursive calls to `setTimeout` pose a problem when doing this, because the recursive `setTimeout` calls are executed synchronously, causing infinite recursion.

title: An inconsistency in zipObjectDeep
body:
The following snippet shows an inconsistency in zipObjectDeep:

`console.log(_.zipObjectDeep(['a.1','a.p','b.p','b.1'],[1,2,3,4]));`

Which displays this in my (nodejs) console:
`{ a: [ , 1, p: 2 ], b: { '1': 4, p: 3 } }`

`a` is instanciated as an array, wile `b` is instanciated as an object, only because the order in which the property paths were specified is different.

I'm sure that in all practical cases, especially practical cases involving numbers used as object property keys, the effects of this should be quite limited, but yet... that's an inconsistency. Also, if I really had wanted an array, I would have said so, writing `a[1]` instead of `a.1`.

Thanks for the nice "little library :).

body:
Trying to parse out a string path intended for lodash, and manipulate it, is pretty daunting. It would be very helpful if they could be parsed into arrays at-will.

In my particular use case, if a `_.get` fails, I want to test if at least the containing object exists. This would be trivially easy if I could use something like `_.castPathToArray`, drop the last element of the result, and throw that into another `_.get`.

title: [feature request] support Map and WeakMap in _.get & _.set & _.update
add _.isEqualIn
body: Addresses https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2876.

title: add support for comparing inherited properties with _.isEqual
body:
Addresses #2876.

The `compareInheritedProperties` param is only added to `_.isEqual()` here but could be extended to other APIs.

title: add support for comparing inherited properties with _.isEqual
body:
Feature request. _.isEqual() only checks own properties when comparing two objects and doesn't check inherited properties. It would be nice to have a codepath to also check inherited properties (we need this in a project where many properties are stored on the prototype). This should be opt-in to avoid affecting perf for the normal case.

Note that a way to achieve this currently is to use `_.toPlainObject()` to flatten the inherited properties down, but this is more expensive than just allowing `_.isEqual()` to compare properties without creating any new objects.

hey, I have a (hopefully only understanding) problem with lodash and the merge, I had in mind merge works like Object.assign, but recursively and arrays will be concatinate. 
But currently also arrays runs through the Object.assign and overrides the elements with the same index.
I'm wrong with it or I had the wrong function in mind does this?

Example (https://jsfiddle.net/r8xxs3vm/):
```
const a = ['a'];
const b = ['b'];
console.log(_.merge(a, b)); // expected: ['a', 'b'], actual: ['b']
```

Background:
We had a upcoming bug in our software that an array inside a config object I use merge gets partly overwritten instead of concatenate without any changes in this part of code.

I just wanted to point out that while reading the documentation on lodash.com, there is an ad (via carbon) that appears and directly blocks a portion of the listed api's on the left side of the page on desktop. At least on my screen it blocks the viewing of the methods flatten, flattenDeep, flattenDepth and fromPairs. Its totally fine if you have ads, just wasn't sure that your intention was to block usability of your site. Thanks, I appreciate all your hard work for this project!

title: FP: Argument-less calls ignore default parameters
body:
I was surprised to discover it is impossible in lodash/fp to partially fill in into any library function its default 
parameter. My expectation was that if I make an argument-less call of a curried function, lodash would use the default parameter for that arg, just like expected in JS or Python. For example: 
```
// JavaScript
let add = (x = 1) => y => x + y;
add()(5)  // 6
add(2)(5) // 7
// Python
add = lambda x=1: lambda y: x + y
add()(5)   # 6
add(2)(5)  # 7
```
But it seems lodash/fp ignores all empty calls until the function has received enough args (all examples here have a fixed arity of two):
```
_.sortBy(_.identity)([3, 1, 2])           // Array [ 1, 2, 3 ]
_.sortBy()([3, 1, 2])                     // function wrapper()
_.sortBy()()()()()([3, 1, 2])             // function wrapper()
_.sortBy()()()()()(_.identity)([3, 1, 2]) // Array [ 1, 2, 3 ]
_.drop()([1, 2, 3])                       // function wrapper()
_.drop(1)([1, 2, 3])                      // Array [ 2, 3 ]
_.random()()                              // function wrapper()
_.random(0)(1)                            // 0
```

Puzzlingly the only mention of this behavior I could find was [one line ("`flow(sortBy())([1, 6, 2]);`")](https://medium.com/making-internets/why-using-chain-is-a-mistake-9bc1f80d51ba#8e81) from the "Why using `_.chain` is a mistake" article, where the author seems to have made the same mistake I did in assuming how an empty call would work.

Am I correct in thinking it would be too complicated to fix this at this stage? Or does it WAI?

I am using lodash/fp v4.17.2 in the browser console.

title: Added new functionality: filterWhile
body: A generalized version of takeWhile and dropWhile

title: Trim/increase array to a size
body:
Given an array I want to ensure it has a certain size. This has 2 cases:

* if the array has a larger size than requested then it needs to be trimmed. For this I want to specify the index where I want to remove the excess elements from -- e.g. `_.ensureSize(NEW_SIZE, {indexStart: 2})`
* if the array has a lower size than requested then I need to add items to the array. For this I want to specify the index where the items to be inserted (or at the end by default) and the value to be added each time -- e.g. `_.ensureSize(NEW_SIZE, {indexStart:-1, newValue:{}})` to append at the end or `_.ensureSize(NEW_SIZE, {indexStart: 3, newValue: "new value"})` to insert items starting at index 3.

title: _.isFunction does not work with async functions
body:
Chrome and Node.js now natively support ES2017 async/await.  However, `_.isFunction()` does not properly detect an async function as a function.  This is because internally, `_.isFunction()` checks for three specific `toString()` tags: `[object Function]`, `[object GeneratorFunction]`, and `[object Proxy]`, but async functions return `[object AsyncFunction]` instead.

```javascript
async function foo() {};
Object.prototype.toString.call(foo);           // --> [object AsyncFunction]
_.isFunction(foo);                             // --> false
```

title: how to use "round" with always "up,down,general"?
body:
I would like to use `round` with always`up, down or general`
```js
_,round(1.234, 2); // general => 1.23

_.round(1.231, 2, 'up'); //always up=> 1.24

_.round(1.239, 2, 'down'); //always down => 1.23
```
please help me.

title: Mention ES6 delimiters in templateSettings docs
body: After a fair amount of confusion and hunting, I finally realized (via #399) that the template function defaults to ERB _and_ ES6 template string delimiters by default. The `templateSettings` docs explicitly mention the ERB style delimiters, but the ES6 style is mentioned only in a code sample comment on the template function itself.

title: Update uglify-js to the latest version ðŸš€
body:
## Version **2.7.5** of [uglify-js](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2) just got published.
Dependency uglify-js
Current Version 2.7.4
Type devDependency
The version **2.7.5** is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of uglify-js. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. ---
Commits

The new version differs by 7 commits .

  • f637248 v2.7.5
  • 98f3306 Generate source map data from normalized files
  • a7b3b0d docs: add doc for option.outFileName
  • 0a35acb feat: add option.outFileName for JS API, if absense, sourceMap.file field will deduced
  • 2a9989d Add --mangle-props-debug and fix --mangle-props=unquoted collision
  • 79b98a9 Do not overwrite options.comments + cleanup
  • 057de57 Pass mangle options to figure_out_scope before mangling in tests

See the full diff.

Not sure how things should work exactly? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and of course you may always [ask my humans](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
--- Your [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io) Bot :palm_tree:

title: Breaking change in omit combined with recursive objects
_.escapeRegExp simply removes backslash
body:
`_.escapeRegExp("\")` result is just an empty string.
But I think it's much more logical to replace it with double backslash `"\\"`.

UPD: My fault. Everything works as expected.

title: Allow to provide a default value for _.invoke, similar to _.get(obj, 'noProp', 'default')
body:
This is a feature request (enhancement) Having an object: ```javascript var obj = { a: 'foo', b: undefined, A: function() {return 'FOO'}, B: function() {return undefined}, } ```
Current _.get Current _.invoke Desired _.invoke
_.get(obj, 'a')
// => "foo"		 _.invoke(obj, 'A')
// => "FOO"		 same
_.get(obj, 'b')
// => undefined		 _.invoke(obj, 'B')
// => undefined		 same
_.get(obj, 'x')
// => undefined		 _.invoke(obj, 'X')
// => undefined		 same
_.invoke(obj, 'a')
// >> Error		 _.invoke(obj, 'a')
// => undefined
_.get(obj, 'b', 'default')
// => "default"		 add _.invoke(obj, 'B', 'default')
// => "default"
_.get(obj, 'x', 'default')
// => "default"		 add _.invoke(obj, 'X', 'default')
// => "default"

title: Documentation: make the documentation about _.isEqual clearer
body:
The documentation of `_.isEqual` [states that](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.2/lodash.js#L11509-L11510):

> Functions and DOM nodes are **not** supported.

Which made me think that giving such objects to the function raises an error, that they don't behave in a coherent way when given to the function, or at least that comparing them is discouraged. Is that on purpose ?

If not, this sentence could be rewritten as:

> Functions and DOM nodes are simply compared with the `===` operator.
